article.title: Transport_in_the_Czech_Republic
article.paragraph: File:Lokomotiva 181 131.jpgthumbright200pxAn electric locomotive in the Czech Republic (1989)Transport in the Czech Republicrelies on several main modes, includingTransportationtransportby road, rail, water and air.
article.heading: Railways

template.arg: Rail transport in the Czech Republic

article.paragraph: The Czech Republic has a total railway length ofconvert9435kmmi. The vast majority (convert9341kmmi) is standard gauge. Electrified railways generally have voltages of 3 kV DC or 25 kV AC.convert94kmmiof track isNarrow gauge railways in the Czech Republicnarrow gauge. The most prominent Czech railway company is the state-ownedesk drhy(D) (English:Czech Railways).Praguehas an undergroundrapid transitsystem, thePrague Metro. In addition, the cities ofBrno,Liberec,Most (Most District)Most,Olomouc,Ostrava,Plze, and Prague have tram systems.
article.heading: Roads

link.part: Map of the Czech highway network

article.paragraph: The Czech Republic has, in total,convert55653kmoncite webhttp://www.iraptranstats.net/czTransport in Czech Republic2008-10-062008-04-13International Transport Statistics Database[[iRAP]]of roads. It hasconvert690.25kmonCite webhttp://www.rsd.cz/rsd/rsd.nsf/0/AE55C3DAD269424BC12575CB0050A3A7/$file/RSD2009en.pdf/Roads and Motorways in the Czech Republic 20092010-06-26rsd.czof motorways. In the 1980s and 1990s there was a significant increase in passenger transport on the roads in the Czech Republic, which was associated with a sharp increase in the accident rate. Between 2007 and 2013, the death rate fell in every year, with a record low of 583 deaths in 2013, compared with the 1994 high of 1,473 casualties.cite webhttp://www.ceskenoviny.cz/news/zpravy/number-of-traffic-victims-in-czechrep-lowest-in-history-in-2013/1025609Number of traffic victims in Czech Republic lowest in history in 2013ceskenoviny.cz1 January 201430 January 2014Despite this however, the fatality rate per head of population is moderately high, comparable to theUnited States.
article.heading: Highways
article.paragraph: The highways in theCzech Republicare divided intoControlled-access highwaymotorwaysandLimited-access roadexpressways.

Thesedual carriagewaysare managed by the state-owned Road and Motorway Directorate of the Czech Republic RSD, established in 1997. The first modern highways in the Czech Republic was the motorway fromPragueto theSlovakiaSlovak borderthroughBrnowhose construction was started on May 2, 1939.
RSD currently manages and maintains 726.9 km of motorways (dlnice) and 391.2 km of expressways (rychlostn silnice).
article.heading: Waterways
article.paragraph: TheVltavais the country's longest river, at 430 km. 358 km of theElbe(Labe), which totals 1154 km, is also present in the country.
article.heading: Ports and harbors
article.paragraph: Dn,Mlnk, Prague,st nad Labem,MoldauhafeninHamburg(no longer operational, will be handed over to Germany in 2028)
article.heading: Airports
article.paragraph: In 2006, the Czech Republic had a total 121 airports. 46 of these airports had paved runways while 75 had unpaved runways. The largest and busiest airport in the Czech Republic isVclav Havel Airport Prague, opened in 1937. Other international airports includeBrno-Tuany Airport,Karlovy Vary Airport,Ostrava Leo Janek Airport,Pardubice Airport,Kunovice Airportand Public domestic and private international airport is for exampleHradec Krlov Airport
